item.question: To print a list of mails currently in the queue, which command would you use?
item.hint: We are talking about mail, not print jobs

item.question: What is the correct order in which the BASH shell will search for a command?
item.hint: When you provide a pathname, i.e. the commandname contains a forward slash, you tell the shell exactly where to find the command. Therefore it does not have to search for it in this case. When you only provide the commandname (i.e. without a forward slash) the shell will search for a command with the given name. This can be either a builtin (shell function) or an executable on a filesystem.

item.question: A user calls claiming that the network does not work. You remember adding an extra network-card to her machine yesterday and did not test the new setup. You have a feeling that the network cards might be conflicting. Which file would you check?
item.hint: If you are not certain you might get lucky and another question may give you a clue for the correct answer.

item.question: What will DNS enable you to do?
item.hint: You might find that DNS is an essential part of the internet, and that without it, the internet just won't work for most people. However, internet stands for internetworking which stands for the practice of connecting a computer network with other networks through the use of gateways that provide a common method of routing information packets between the networks. Hence, DNS may use an internet to provide its services but techically does not manage or provide access to the internet.

item.question: Your senior sysadmin created the script show above to create a daily backup of the directory <font face="monospace">/data</font> on multiple servers and sent each backup to the backupserver. However, you notice that sometimes backups are missing. To check if the backup succeeded you want to extend above script. Which of the following would sent an email showing the status of the backup and the date the backup was made.
item.hint: Using <font face="monospace">&&</font> and/or <font face="monospace">||</font> will only check the exit value of the previous command. Also note the usage of double and single quotes.

item.question: You need to add user guru0 to the group students. Which of the following commands will be BEST to perform this task?
item.hint: These kind of questions are great for answering other questions, as it clearly tells you which command you can use to modify a user account. To answer this question correctly you must know which option will add the group to the user's additional groups. Although you can make the user a member of the group by changing its primary group. The question mentions adding the user to the group and not replacing acurrent group membership. So your safest bet would be to add the group to the user's additional groups.

item.question: Consider the above exhibit. What does the number <font face="monospace">20738</font> represent?
item.choice: the process ID of the last command executed in the background
the process ID of the echo command
the process ID of the last command executed in the foreground
the process ID of the current shell
item.correct_answer: the process ID of the current shell
item.hint: If you are not certain you might get lucky and another question may give you a clue for the correct answer.

item.question: Which command allows you to make a shell variable visible to subshells?
item.hint: If you want the shell to replace a variable with its contents you should precede it with a dollar sign ($). If you want to manipulate a variable you should only specify its name (without the <font face="monospace">$</font>). The command <font face="monospace">set</font> is used to configure the shell. Executing <font face="monospace">set</font> without arguments will print all defined variables. The command <font face="monospace">env</font> can be used to run a program in a modified environment. Running <font face="monospace">env</font> without any arguments will show the current environment. The command <font face="monospace">export</font> is a shell builtin to add variables for automatic inclusion to the enviroment of subsequently executed commands.

item.question: The above exhibit for contains a line from the file <font face="monospace">/etc/passwd</font>. Which of the following statements is true, based on the information in the exhibit?
item.choice: User <font face="monospace">guru1</font> belongs to the group with GID 5102.
The username <font face="monospace">guru1</font> belongs to the group <font face="monospace">GURU 1</font>.
Members of the group with GID 5001 can read directory <font face="monospace">/home/guru1</font>.
The file <font face="monospace">/etc/passwd</font> is corrupt as you may not use space-characters in a passwd-entry.
item.hint: If you are not certain you might get lucky and another question may give you a clue for the correct answer.

item.question: What does the syslog facility <font face="monospace">uucp</font> stand for?
item.hint: Although it is hardly used on Linux you might have encountered it setting up logging services. If you did, then as a curious sysadmin you immediately looked it up on the interweb ;-). If you didn't, well it probably has to do something with Unix.....

item.question: Select the line that best represents the permissions for the file <font face="monospace">/etc/passwd</font>.
item.hint: The file <font face="monospace">/etc/passwd</font> is used by many programs to locate the homedirectory of a user or get the username associated with a user ID. If permissions were to be too strict a lot of user friendliness would be disabled. For instance tilde substitution by the shell.

item.question: Consider the above command. What does the argument <font face="monospace">-s</font> do?
item.choice: Specify the default shell for the user <font face="monospace">guru1</font>
Show the account settings for <font face="monospace">guru1</font>
Nothing, as <font face="monospace">useradd</font> does not know about an option <font face="monospace">-s</font>
item.correct_answer: Specify the default shell for the user <font face="monospace">guru1</font>
item.hint: Most programs try to make the options as intuitive as possible. They usually are the first letter of the spelled out option name.

item.question: What is the output when the above shell script executes?
item.choice: The contents of the file guru.
No output but a file named guru is created.
item.hint: If you are not certain you might get lucky and another question may give you a clue for the correct answer.

item.question: During your monthly security audit on a RedHat system you want to check if any files from the package <font face="monospace">cups</font> have changed since installation. Which command with all needed options provides you with this information?
item.hint: What you are looking for is package verification, also known as verify...

item.question: Which of the following lines would you expect to see in the file <font face="monospace">/etc/hosts.allow</font>?
item.hint: The format of the <font face="monospace">hosts.allow</font> file is service name (proces name) followed by the access control rule or rules.

item.question: You discovered a pending job for the <font face="monospace">at</font>-command. Which of the following do you have to use to remove it?
item.hint: If you are not certain you might get lucky and another question may give you a clue for the correct answer.

item.question: The _________ command is used to modify or set the password expiration for a user.
item.hint: There are multiple commands that allow you to set or modify the expiration date for an account. Any of these commands is a correct answer.

item.question:
Which command will tell you the geometry of a X window application?
Choose all that apply.
item.hint: Sometimes the command name says it all. You require information regarding a X window...

item.question: Which of the following lines from a <font face="monospace">syslog</font> configuration file would sent all log messages to the remote log server <font face="monospace">loggy.atcomputing.nl</font>
item.hint: Syslog uses facilities and priorities to differentiate log messages. The facility and priority are separated by a dot. Although there is not a general consensus on what to use for all, the asterisk (*) is often used to specify all. In computer science the @ symbol is often used to refer to a different host on a network.

item.question: Which of the following websites provide linux related news?
item.hint: You either know 'em or you don't. If you don't better check them out regularly to keep up to date.

item.question: The ______ command is used to print out the current date and time on the system.
item.hint: The question does not state if you should print the hardware or system time. Therefore, you may assume both are correct.

item.question: The _________ command is used to send ECHO_REQUEST packets.
item.hint: An ECHO_REQUEST is an ICMP message whose data is expected back to the sender in a ECHO_REPLY packet. It is used mostly to check if the remote host is reachable over a network.

item.question:
What syslog facility represents user authentication processes?
(Select all correct answers)
item.hint: If you are not certain you might get lucky and another question may give you a clue for the correct answer.

item.question: The correct command to view ALL line printer queues is?
item.hint: If you are not certain you might get lucky and another question may give you a clue for the correct answer.

item.question: Your logfiles are getting very large and you decide to exclude all log messages of a given logging facility. Which priority should you use?
item.hint: If you are not certain you might get lucky and another question may give you a clue for the correct answer.

item.question: What is the file <font face="monospace">/etc/host.conf</font> used for?
item.choice: To hold the hostname of the machine
To hold ip-address and hostname translations
To specify which other hosts are allowed to connect to this machine
item.hint: Not many sysadmins know of this file but it does exist. Although you will never need to edit this file we thought it might be nice to include some of the peculiarities of the Linux system as well. Its purpose was to configure the resolver library implemented in libc. It was used by an older version of libc (before glibc version 2) and it seems that it is not used anymore. However, glibc still reads the file but does not do anything with the contents. It has been superseded by the file <font face="monospace">/etc/nsswitch.conf</font>.

item.question: Which section in the file <font face="monospace">/etc/X11/xorg.conf</font> allows you to specify the video resolutions for specific colour depths?
item.hint: A single Xorg server can manage multiple screens on multiple monitors. For each screen you can specify the video resolution and colour depth.

item.question: You want to make sure all users, when they login, get access to a new program in <font face="monospace">/opt/bin</font> (not currently in their PATH). To ensure this you would put the command in above exhibit in what file? (provide full pathname)
item.hint: If you are not certain you might get lucky and another question may give you a clue for the correct answer.

item.question: Which command can you use to set limits on resources available to the processes you start from a shell?
item.hint: If you are not certain you might get lucky and another question may give you a clue for the correct answer.

item.question:
A user working in Cameroon calls and asks you if there is a way to set the time to her localtime on the server running in Amsterdam.
Which of the following programs would you advice her?
item.hint: The question is about providing the user a tool that allows her to select and set the correct timezone for her login account.

item.question: What file contains kernel level logging information such as output from a kernel module when it is loaded?
item.hint: The question does not state what flavour and in that case you should assume a default Debian or RedHat setup. Answers that apply to either one will be considered correct.

item.question: Which of the following tools is used to configure CUPS?
item.hint: If you are not certain you might get lucky and another question may give you a clue for the correct answer.

item.question: You want to copy all files in the current directory to the directory <font face="monospace">/tmp/guru</font>. Which of the following scripts will copy all regular files without generating any file-permission errors knowing that you have write permissions for <font face="monospace">/tmp/guru</font>?
item.hint: We went a little overboard on this question and provided many choices with subtle differences. Read all choices very carefully and pay good attention to the if-statements.

item.question: You have replaced <font face="monospace">inetd</font> with <font face="monospace">xinetd</font>. What must be done after installation to ensure that your machine will work correctly?
item.choice: You must add a symbolic link from <font face="monospace">inetd.conf</font> to <font face="monospace">xinetd.conf</font>.
You must convert the file <font face="monospace">inetd.conf</font> to the configuration file format used by <font face="monospace">xinetd</font>.
You don't have to do anything because they are compatible.
You must convert and copy the file <font face="monospace">inetd.conf</font> to <font face="monospace">xinetd.conf</font>
item.correct_answer: You don't have to do anything because they are compatible.
item.hint: <font face="monospace">xinetd</font> is backwards compatible with <font face="monospace">inetd</font>. This does not mean that <font face="monospace">xinetd</font> will just read the same configuration files as <font face="monospace">inetd</font> does. However, if you look at the possible choices only one will match this description. Note the direction of the symbolic link that is made in one of the options...

item.question: In the passwd file, you changed <font face="monospace">/bin/bash</font> to <font face="monospace">/bin/false</font> for user bob. What best describes the effect on bob's account?
item.choice: When bob logs in on a terminal screen he will immediately logout.
Bob will be asked to provide a new shell to use
item.correct_answer: When bob logs in on a terminal screen he will immediately logout.
item.hint: The default shell for a specific user is specified in the file <font face="monospace">/etc/passwd</font>. The default shell specification should point to an executable that is started by a terminal when it needs to run a shell. The program <font face="monospace">/bin/false</font> will do nothing but exit with an exit code indicating a failure.

item.question:
Consider the following commandline:
What does the above commandline do?
item.choice: Syntax error as an opening bracket must be preceeded by an <font face="monospace">if</font>-keyword.
Execute <font face="monospace">/usr/bin/xterm</font> if it has execution permission set.
Check if <font face="monospace">/usr/bin/xterm</font> has execution permissions and if so will not execute <font face="monospace">/usr/bin/xterm</font>
Simultaneously run two instances of <font face="monospace">/usr/bin/xterm</font>
item.correct_answer: Execute <font face="monospace">/usr/bin/xterm</font> if it has execution permission set.
item.hint: The <font face="monospace">&&</font> is a logical AND which is evaluated in a lazy manner from left to right. This means that if the left program fails the next program or programs are not executed. The <font face="monospace">[</font> is an actual program that implements a test operation. It will stop with exit code 0 if the test passes and will return an exit code other than 0 if the test fails.

item.question: Which of the following commandlines will stop all running processes with the name <font face="monospace">catchme</font>? (Select two)
item.hint: The command <font face="monospace">ps</font> will show a header which will not contain valid input for the <font face="monospace">kill</font> command. Also, be sure to pick TWO answers. Any other amount is incorrect.

item.question: You attached a scsi-device to your system and want to check if the kernel detects the device. Which commandline is BEST to use to see which scsi-devices are connected?
item.hint: The question is about the KERNEL detecting the device and not UDEV. Therefore, the <font face="monospace">/dev</font> directory can be disregarded. The kernel uses a special filesystem to display system information. This filesystem is not located on disk but maintained in memory. However, you can access the contents as if it were normal files and directories on a disk.

item.question: Your senior system administrator asks you to do a routinely security audit on a couple of systems. One of the tasks is to get a list of programs that when executed as a normal user will run with root privileges. Which of the following commands would you use to generate such a list?
item.hint: Apparently you are looking for setuid permissions on files, as all choices are concerned with setuid. The program <font face="monospace">locate</font> will not allow you to filter on permissions. The command <font face="monospace">ls</font> might be an option but the <font face="monospace">grep</font> command will only show you directories. So, you are left with two options. Now all you need to know to answer this question correctly, is that for <font face="monospace">find</font> permissions specified after a <font face="monospace">/</font> are logically ORed.

item.question:
Consider above output from a SQL select statement. What would be the result if you execute the following SQL statement?
UPDATE users SET Rank = "Senior"
item.choice: Nothing as you did not specify which row needs to be updated.
All users will be promoted to the rank Senior.
Error as you did not specify which row needs to be updated.
item.correct_answer: All users will be promoted to the rank Senior.
item.hint: By default SQL will affect all rows unless specified otherwise.

item.question: You need to convert a textfile using the WINDOWS-1253 character encoding to UTF-8. Which of the following commands allows you to do this?
item.hint: You might be in doubt about <font face="monospace">convert</font>. However, the tool <font face="monospace">convert</font> is used to convert between image formats and not character encoding schemes.

item.question: A user says she would like to use <font face="monospace">joe</font> as her default editor. Which of the following files would you edit to make sure the editor is always set as default when the user logs in?
item.hint: If you are not certain you might get lucky and another question may give you a clue for the correct answer.

item.question: Which <font face="monospace">syslog</font> facility is used by the <font face="monospace">cron</font> daemon?
item.hint: Sometimes the facility matches the name of the daemon.

item.question:
A user guru0 complains that he can not execute a script called makemeroot as shown above.
Which permission is needed to allow the user to execute the script?
item.hint: The question mentions that the command is a script. A script needs to be interpreted by another program. Therefore it is not the script itself that is executed. It only contains the command lines that must be executed.

item.question: You notice that a lot of users complain that reading manpages is very inconvenient and ask you if you can change the pager to use the command <font face="monospace">less</font> instead of <font face="monospace">more</font>. Which of the following files would you edit to make this change.
item.hint: The default pager can be set through the <font face="monospace">PAGER</font> variable. Therefore, you will need to find a way to set the <font face="monospace">PAGER</font> variable each time a user logs in and starts a shell. Also note that the skel directory is only effective for new users. The question is about changing the pager for current users as well.

item.question: The _________ file configures the <font face="monospace">syslogd</font> logging daemon.
item.hint: As the question does not mention anything about providing a pathname you may assume it is optional.

item.question: Users complain they cannot login to a server. However, you have no problem remote logging in as root. What best explains this situation?
item.choice: The file <font face="monospace">/etc/shadow</font> is not present.
The presence of the file <font face="monospace">/etc/nologin</font>.
The set-uid bit on <font face="monospace">/bin/login</font> is missing.
item.correct_answer: The presence of the file <font face="monospace">/etc/nologin</font>.
item.hint: The question does not state anything about remote logins. Therefore, any options regarding remote logins can be discarded. You are now still left with multiple options. From there you should select the most probable reason for the stated problem.

item.question: Which command generated the output in above exhibit?
item.hint: If you are not certain you might get lucky and another question may give you a clue for the correct answer.

item.question: You are the system administrator for a consulting firm where several people use Linux as their desktop operating system. One of your users has installed a commercial publishing program that works under X on a variety of UNIX and Linux platforms. The user made a series of configuration changes regarding the initial window size, location and color. Now, he is having difficulty undoing these changes and is asking for your help. Which of the following files contains most likely the configurations changes?
item.hint: If you are not certain you might get lucky and another question may give you a clue for the correct answer.

item.question: Which of the following are window managers? Choose all correct answers.
item.hint: Remember a window manager is not the same as a desktop manager. Although sometimes they are combined.

item.question: Alice calls to complain that she is not allowed to create a crontab entry. You setup a default deny for crontab usage. Which file would you most likely need to edit to give her access?
item.hint: If you are not certain you might get lucky and another question may give you a clue for the correct answer.

item.question: Which command is used to view the queue for the <font face="monospace">at</font>-command?
item.hint: If not stated explicitly assume only the command name is required and not the path as well.

item.question: Consider above exhibit. Which of the following statements about <font face="monospace">/var/log/rpmpkgs</font> is true?
item.choice: It is rotated once a week
If the file is missing it will be recreated
It does not exist on Linux system
item.correct_answer: It is rotated once a week
item.hint: The exhibit shows the partial contents of a configuration file for <font face="monospace">logrotate</font>. Usually there are also some global settings, however these are not shown. Therefore, you cannot know for sure that the file, if missing, will be recreated after rotation. The option <font face="monospace">notifempty</font> refers to <font face="monospace">logrotate</font> not rotating this file if it is empty.

item.question: You downloaded a script and notice that the first line starts with <font face="monospace">#!</font>. What is the purpose of this line?
item.choice: The command after the <font face="monospace">#!</font> will replace the script
The command after the <font face="monospace">#!</font> will be executed to interpret the script.
The <font face="monospace">#!</font> sign tells the shell where to start executing the script
The line will be ignored as it starts with <font face="monospace">#</font>
item.correct_answer: The command after the <font face="monospace">#!</font> will be executed to interpret the script.
item.hint: The <font face="monospace">#!</font> is used by the kernel to determine which interpreter must be started to actually read and execute the script.

item.question: Which file is used by TCP Wrapper to determine which connections should be denied for a network service? (Provide the full path)
item.hint: If you are not certain you might get lucky and another question may give you a clue for the correct answer.

item.question: You notice that the automatic configuration of <font face="monospace">Xorg</font> fails. You now want to generate a configuration file for <font face="monospace">Xorg</font>. Which of the following commands allows you to generate a template configuration file?
item.hint: The command <font face="monospace">xf86config</font> is used by the XFree86 implementation of the X Window System. The question is about the Xorg implementation.

item.question: You want the script <font face="monospace">cleanup</font> to be executed each thursday at 04:00. Which of the following crontab entries would you use?
item.hint: The format for a user crontab entry is: minutes, hours, day of month, month, day of week, command. A <font face="monospace">*</font> means every minute, hour, day of month, etc. etc.

item.question: Which of the following fields are required in the <font face="monospace">/etc/passwd</font> file for a user account? (Choose all that apply)
item.hint: If you are not certain you might get lucky and another question may give you a clue for the correct answer.

item.question: In which of the following configuration files can you connect hostnames to ip-addresses?
item.hint: If you are not certain you might get lucky and another question may give you a clue for the correct answer.

item.question: You want the command <font face="monospace">atc2</font> only to be executed when the command <font face="monospace">atc1</font> fails. Which of the following command lines will allow this?
item.hint: <font face="monospace">&&</font> stands for AND. <font face="monospace">||</font> stands for OR. These are evaluated from left to right using lazy evaluation. This means that if evaluating the next condition does not matter for the overall result, the next condition or conditions will not be evaluated. If you use a logical OR the overall result will be true if at least one of the conditions is true. If you use a logical AND all conditions must be true to make the overall result become true. Therefore, if you use a logical OR and the left command fails the next command will be executed. If the left command succeeds there is no need to execute the next command. When using a logical AND the next command will only be executed if the left command succeeded.
